metadata.title: Envisioning nano release dynamics in a changing world: using dynamic probabilistic modelling to assess future environmental emissions of engineered nanoparticles

Article
Envisioning nano release dynamics in a changing world: using dynamic probabilistic modelling to assess future environmental emissions of engineered nanoparticles
Tianyin Sun, Denise M. Mitrano, Nikolaus A Bornhöft, Martin Scheringer, Konrad Hungerbuehler, and Bernd Nowack
Environ. Sci. Technol., Just Accepted Manuscript • DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.6b05702 • Publication Date (Web): 03 Feb 2017
Downloaded from http://pubs.acs.org on February 6, 2017

Envisioning nano release dynamics in a changing world: using dynam-1
ic probabilistic modelling to assess future environmental emissions of 2
engineered nanoparticles 3
4
Tian Yin Sun 1,2 , Denise M. Mitrano 1 , Nikolaus A. Bornhöft 1,3 , Martin Scheringer 2,4 , Konrad 5 Hungerbühler2 and Bernd Nowack1* 6

ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
TOC Art 22

Page 2 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
Abstract 25
The need for an environmental risk assessment for engineered nanomaterials (ENM) necessi-26 tates the knowledge about their environmental emissions. Material flow models (MFA) have 27 been used to provide predicted environmental emissions but most current nano-MFA models 28 consider neither the rapid development of ENM production nor the fact that a large proportion 29 of ENM are entering an in-use stock and are released from products over time (i.e. have a lag 30 phase). Here we use dynamic probabilistic material flow modelling to predict scenarios of the 31 future flows of four ENM (nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, nano-Ag and CNT) to environmental com-32 partments and to quantify their amounts in (temporary) sinks such as the in-use stock and (“fi-33 nal”) environmental sinks such as soil and sediment. In these scenarios, we estimate likely fu-34 ture amounts if the use and distribution of ENM in products continues along current trends (i.e. 35 a business-as-usual approach) and predict the effect of hypothetical trends in the market devel-36 opment of nanomaterials, such as the emergence of a new widely used product or the ban on 37 certain substances, on the flows of nanomaterials to the environment in years to come. We show 38 that depending on the scenario and the product type affected, significant changes of the flows 39 occur over time, driven by the growth of stocks and delayed release dynamics. 40
41
Introduction 42
The fast-paced growth of the nanotechnology industry brings novel materials into commercially 43 available products on a frequent basis and these engineered nanomaterials (ENM) will be re-44 leased during the products’ life-cycle. Modelling approaches play an indispensable role in un-45 derstanding and predicting nanomaterial concentrations in the environment that cannot be re-46 placed by analytical measurements. Current modelling efforts have approximated the mass 47 flows to and the concentrations of ENM in environmental and technical compartments, allowing 48 researchers from many disciplines to perform more realistic studies concerning environmental 49 health and safety.1-10 The preferred approach follows a life-cycle principle tracking ENM mass-50 flows (material flow analysis, MFA) from the production of ENM through to their final settling 51 place in environmental or waste streams. Validation of these models proves difficult as analyti-52 cal measurements in target systems remain largely elusive 11 . However, all these models were 53 static and did not consider time-dependent processes with respect to the use of nanoproducts and 54 release of ENM, which will become an increasingly important factor in the future. 55
Static MFA models for ENM represent an oversimplification of the system in two respects; 1) 56 only input from production, manufacturing and consumption that occurs in one year is account-57 ed for and then distributed over the system immediately and 2) the assumption that all ENM 58
Page 3 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
produced and applied in products are released to waste streams and the environment in the same 59 year in which they enter the system. These pitfalls will become increasingly apparent as the 60 number of products that contain nanomaterials begin to increase on the market and the accumu-61 lation of significant stocks of ENM in the anthroposphere, which currently are not considered, 62 continues. It is particularly important to account for realistic releases into technical and envi-63 ronmental compartments over a product life-time of many years. The release from these stocks 64 is not necessarily an immediate or linear process but rather one that is dependent on how ENM 65 are used in products and is related to specific releases dictated by their use and disposal path-66
ways 12, 13 . 67
While first attempts have been made in considering accumulation in environmental sinks, such 68 as soil, and sediment 7, 14 , these models cannot predict accurate and realistic emissions into these 69 compartments because the dynamics of production and release from products have not been tak-70 en into account. For a limited system only involving waste incineration plants, Walser and 71 Gottschalk attempted to adapt older models for dynamic material transfer between compart-72 ments. 15 73
A paradigm shift in the MFA modelling process for ENM is needed to ensure that new models 74 are developed which have a dynamic nature that can encompass the inclusion of ENM stocks. 75 This is an indispensable element of MFA for modelling substance metabolism in the anthropo-76 sphere 16 . Conceptually, this modelling approach is different from previous models used to ap-77 proximate ENM emissions/flows into various environmental compartments in its levels of so-78 phistication, accuracy and therefore applicability. This step towards a more holistic modelling 79 scheme comes from the convergence of two existing modelling methods: probabilistic materials 80 flow analysis (P-MFA) and dynamic material-flow analysis (D-MFA). With P-MFA, uncertainty 81 in the data used for a given model parameter is addressed as a probability distribution, therefore 82
representing the comprehensive picture of the current understanding. D-MFA 17-19 is able to as-83 sess the past, present and future flows of a material relying on knowledge of how the target sys-84 tem behaves and does not use the simplified assumption of immediate releases into the system 85 with the additional inclusion of stocks and timed releases. Uncertainty in the system is not usu-86 ally emphasised in D-MFA20. The dynamic probabilistic MFA (DP-MFA) method recently de-87 veloped by Bornhöft et al. fills this gap 21 . This method provides information about the behav-88 iour of the system as a function of time while representing all uncertain system parameters as 89 probability distributions. Built on this general DP-MFA framework, Sun et al. 22 developed a 90 customised dynamic probabilistic material flow model predicting the mass-flows of four ENM – 91 nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, nano-Ag, and CNT – to technical and environmental compartments and 92 the resulting concentrations in these compartments over time. One of the main assumptions of 93 Sun et al. is that the share of ENM applied in different products remains constant over time. 94
Page 4 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
However, this is a simplification, especially in a world with a rapid advancement of technology 95 and the appearance and establishment of new products alongside increased regulatory measures 96 that seek to limit facets of this technology. 97
The aims of this work were to predict scenarios of future flows of four ENM (nano-TiO2, nano-98 ZnO, nano-Ag and CNT) to environmental compartments. In these scenarios, we estimate future 99 amounts if the use of ENM in products continues along current trends and predict the effect of 100 hypothetical trends in the market development of nanomaterials. 101
Methods 102
General principle 103
The general principle of the DP-MFA21 model can be summarised by the following three fea-104 tures: 1) the use of a life-cycle concept, 2) the application of a probabilistic approach and 3) dy-105 namic considerations. Following a life-cycle concept, the model tracks the mass-flows of four 106 ENM (nano-Ag, nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, and CNT) from ENM production to incorporation into 107 commercial products and finally from the products to technical and environmental compart-108 ments during/after their use and disposal 12 . We estimated the release of ENM from products as 109 described in Sun et al22. Probabilistic methods were employed for all the parameters used in the 110 modelling processes to address the inherent uncertainty in the raw data used 23 . The dynamic 111 considerations in this work are comprised of three aspects: the input dynamics, the dynamics of 112 use scenarios and the release dynamics. The input dynamics describe the annual production of 113 ENM as inflows into the system within a given period. The dynamics of the allocation to nano-114 products address the change of the share of ENM in different products over time. The release 115 dynamics describe the time-dependent ENM release kinetics from a specific product category 116 over its entire lifecycle. 117
DP-MFA is separated into two modules21: the release module and the distribution module, as 118 depicted in Figure 1. The release module addresses the input dynamics, the use scenarios and 119 the (product) release dynamics. It describes the annual ENM production entering the anthropo-120 sphere system in the European Union (EU) over a period, the changes of the ENM-shares in 121 product categories, and the flows from product categories by immediate release or into in-use 122 stocks and finally the release from in-use stocks. “In-use stocks” in our model represent those 123 ENM that are contained in products or applications during a use-phase that is longer than one 124 year. The total annual release of ENM is then transferred to the compartments of the distribution 125 module. The distribution module is built upon our previous static model 3 , which describes the 126 ENM transfers within and between technical and environmental compartments. 127
Page 5 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
128
129
Use: Use phase release; EoL: End of Life phase release. 130
Figure 1: Schematic visualization of the release module (input dynamics, mass distribution and 131 the time dependent ENM release dynamics) and the distribution module (movement of ENM 132 to/among technical and environmental compartments after product release). Hourglass symbols 133 represent a phase in the release cycle where product-dependent timed releases occur defined by 134 the life cycle of the given product and the expected yearly releases associated with use and dis-135 posal over the products lifetime. Stop watches indicate places where releases of ENM are 136 stocked and “stored” for later release in future yearly cycles. In the distribution module, tech-137 nical systems/compartments include wastewater treatment, waste incineration, landfill and re-138 cycling; environment indicates compartments of air, soil, surface water and sediment. Releases 139 from production/manufacturing are considered but not depicted in this scheme. 140
141
Input dynamics 142
The estimation of production of ENM over time was determined by multiplying the base year 143 production (2012) with retrospective and prospective scaling factors as described in the Sup-144 porting Information. The production of the four ENM in 2012 is based on updated probability 145 distributions3, 22. The scaling factors for each individual year were based on ENM market pro-146 jections, nanotechnology patent analysis and direct information on ENM production when 147 available22. We used the assumption that the development of ENM production is proportional to 148 nanotechnology development. 149
150
Product release dynamics 151
Page 6 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
In our definition, release refers to ENM that leaves the production, manufacturing and consump-152 tion (use) phase and is subsequently transferred to technical or environmental compartments. 153 ENM that reside in the in-use stock are not yet considered released. The scheme in Figure 1 de-154 picts how ENM are released in a time-dependent manner from products. Modelling the release 155 of ENM from products to environmental and/or technical compartments proceeds in three steps: 156 1) separation of ENM allocated in one product category into the “Use release” and/or “End of 157 Life (EoL) release”; 2) scheduling of Use and EoL releases, i.e. allocating timed release from 158 each product category in the use phase or product disposal; and 3) distribution of ENM into 159 technical and/or environmental compartment(s) after leaving the Use release and/or EoL release 160 at the specified time. The magnitude of the mass of ENM moving from one stage in a compart-161 ment to the next takes into account the amount of ENM in the originating compartment but also 162 hinges on the transfer coefficients (TC), where TC values are summarized in our previous stud-163 ies 3, 22 . An example of the release parameters is given in Table S2 (Supplementary Information). 164 SI Table S3 provides the new TC values for CNT applied in tyres. 165
The time line of ENM release from products and into the environment or technical compart-166 ments were established alongside the complete product life times to establish a timed-release 167 schedule. The release kinetics of ENM are specific to which products the ENM are used in, 168 which ENM is applied and how the ENM is bound in a product. Preferably, this information is 169 based on experimental data but it was estimated by expert judgement when no experimental re-170 sults were available. The EoL release is dictated by the lifetime of the product. Product lifetimes 171 are often independent of ENM application, therefore the period of time a product is used before 172 it is disposed of is either well known or can be easily estimated. A detailed description of the pa-173 rameters used for the product use schedule and the EoL release schedule is given in the Support-174 ing Information. 175
The model includes some ENM transformation reactions during release or in technical com-176 partments3, but no further fate in environmental sinks, such as soils, is considered. Additionally, 177 some transformation processes of ENM may make them inherently loose their “nano” proper-178 ties, such as when ENM dissolve, become irreversibly complexed to natural particles, or be 179 transformed during some stages of the product life-cycle.24 Therefore, the values given for ENM 180 in environmental sinks represent upper limits for total ENM concentrations. 181
182
Definition of use scenarios 183
We defined six scenarios to explore possible ENM developments. The total ENM production is 184 assigned to different nano-enabled product categories (e.g. cosmetics, textiles, paints, etc.) in 185 shares based on the information provided by our previous work.3 This allocation of ENM to 186
Page 7 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
product categories is assumed to remain constant over the timeline considered in this study 187 (1990 to 2020) for the base scenario. For hypothetical scenarios, such as a ban or increase of 188 ENM in a specific application, a gradual change of the share of ENM allocated to a specific 189 product is considered and the timeline is extended to better exemplify the ramifications of the 190 situation. The settings and assumptions of the chosen scenarios are summarised in Table 1. 191
192
Business as usual (Base scenario - BASE) 193
The business as usual approach is based on the production and mass allocation to products of 194 ENM from 1990 to 2020 and assumes that after 2020 the release remains at the same values as 195 in 2020. No realistic market projections after this date are available and thus a conservative ap-196 proach is adopted and the base scenario is defined as the production value and product distribu-197 tion with no changes. This scenario serves as a baseline to the product-specific scenarios listed 198 below and is a snapshot of how the situation would develop if current ENM development and 199 usage trends persist. 200
201
Cease nano production and application (ENM Ban - BAN) 202
To better understand the model dynamics, specifically to uncover the importance of in-use 203 stocks and timed releases of ENM into technical and environmental compartments, we supposed 204 a hypothetical ban on the use of nano-enhanced products in the year 2020. Where previous 205 models considered ENM to be immediately released to various system compartments the year 206 after production, the in-use stocks central to the DP-MFA model show more complex release 207 dynamics in the years leading up to and after halting ENM production and incorporation into 208 new products. With production completely halted, we observe the evolution of ENM mass ac-209 cumulation in various compartments over time until the in-use stocks of ENM have been com-210 pletely depleted. This thought experiment provides an analysis of how long ENM would remain 211 in the consumer realm and how releases to various system compartments would evolve although 212 there are no new inputs to the system aside from the remaining in-use stock. 213
214
Selective increase or ban of individual nano-enhanced products 215
A more refined approach in understanding more probable ENM dynamics opposed to a simple 216 overarching ban was considered as a next step. The flexibility of the model allows us to amend 217 selected product categories in terms of total production input, release rate, etc. Here we explore 218 the possibilities of innovative products coming to market, which would drastically increase the 219
Page 8 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
production and implementation of a given ENM in a certain product category or, conversely, a 220 legislative ban on ENM in a certain product for e.g. health and safety concerns. In each case, we 221 can observe the dynamic changes one product category can make due to its application volume 222 on the long-term release potential of a specific ENM. This results in a chain reaction affecting 223 the in-use stock and the final releases into environmental and technical compartments in the 224 coming years. In both cases, the hypothetical augmentation of production values was compared 225 to the business as usual (BASE) values. The scenarios put forward in this work include: a ban of 226 nano-TiO2 in cosmetics 25, a ban of nano-Ag in textiles 26, increased use of nano-TiO2 in con-227 crete in building and road constructions 27 and finally the increased production of CNT for use 228 in tyres28, 29. Many of these scenarios have been previously advocated by NGOs, scientists or 229 companies and thus the results presented in this study can help to determine the impact of these 230 calls to ENM management. The detailed transfer factors used for the scenarios are given in the 231 Supporting Information. 232
In the cases of banned items, a new policy to phase out products is not instantaneous from one 233 year to another and therefore the total share of ENM in a certain product category of interest 234 was linearly decreased from the material distribution in the year 2015 until the ban year (2020), 235 thus gradually reaching the target proportion (0%) over a span of five years. Two hypothetical 236 scenarios are shown representing divergent ENM release patterns and product market shares. 237 One product (nano-TiO2 in cosmetics) makes up a dominant fraction (60%) of total use of nano-238 TiO2 to date and has total, immediate release in one year; thus exemplifying a situation where 239 no in-use stock will be carried over in future years once the ban has taken place. Conversely, the 240 examination of a ban of nano-Ag in textiles constitutes a decidedly smaller market share of Ag 241 products (25%) but the in-use stock has longer viability; thus having smaller yet longer-term 242 impact on total nano-Ag output into various environmental and technical sectors over time. 243
As was the case with banned materials, implementation and adoption of new technology slowly 244 gains popularity and thus a linear increase of ENM in target categories was used. The justifica-245 tion for increasing nano-TiO2 in concrete from 0% to 10% arose from recent estimates that this 246 use might be one of the main high-volume applications for photocatalytic nano-TiO2 27. This ap-247 plication serves to illustrate the increased use of a material that has a long life span and there-248 fore slow releases of large in-use stocks. Currently, CNT usage in polymer nano-composites 249 drives the flow of this material with more than 99% of the annual flows of CNT coming from 250 the in-use stock and only very little immediate release. Given that CNT can improve tyre dura-251 bility, this technology may come to the market in the future 28, 29 and so we hypothesized an in-252 creased market share from 0% to 10% of tyres produced which contain CNT. This application 253 serves as an example where the innovation drives a large increase in ENM (CNT) production 254 and causes immediate and steady release over the use phase of the products’ lifetime.255
Page 9 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
Page 10 of 22
Environmental Science & Technology
Results and discussion 259
ENM production over time 260
Figure 2a depicts the modelled production development of nano-TiO2 in the EU between 1990 and 261 2020. Results for nano-TiO2 are demonstrated here as an example because they have the largest pro-262 duction volume amongst the four ENM considered in this study; the results for other ENM can be 263 found in SI Figures S1. The full probability spectrum of the production development is used as the 264 main input for the dynamic flow modelling. The grey dots represent single model runs with single val-265 ues randomly selected out of the underlying probability distributions. The denser the grey dots appear, 266 the more likely the modelled value is. The mean value is shown by the red line. The uncertainty is 267 quantified by the width of the gap between the 15% and 85% quantiles (dashed blue lines). The large 268 spread of the values is a consequence of combining a suite of raw data on development of nanotech-269 nology that diverge quite significantly from each other. The probabilistic modelling is able to synthe-270 size these data. This approach is needed because no historical data on the actual development of the 271 production of ENM are available (with the exception of CNT)30. We have based our model on the as-272 sumption that the development of nanotechnology also reflects the trend of the production of ENM, 273 where more research, patents and scientific papers correlate to real increases in production of nano-274 enhanced products. 275
276
Evolution of ENM in stocks and sinks from realistic estimation and hypothetical extension of produc-277 tion (BASE scenario) 278 Figure 2b provides a full picture of the likelihood of the distribution of the nano-TiO2 development in 279 in-use stocks of products in the EU from 1990 to 2030, with modelled values from 1990 to 2020 based 280 on real production values and after 2020 the hypothetical BASE scenario is envisioned. This is visual-281 ized by single simulations (grey lines) of 100,000 iterations with the mean value (red line) and 15% 282 and 85% quantiles (dashed blue lines). Notably, while the total net amount of ENM in the in-use stock 283 is currently increasing because of assumed increased input from new nanomaterials in the BASE sce-284 nario, other scenarios may not always exhibit sustained growth in all sectors of the in-use stock over 285 time. Figure 2c highlights the mean values of nano-TiO2 accumulated after production and the amount 286 accumulated in the in-use stock, landfills, sludge treated soil and sediment, from which we can deter-287 mine the dominant fate of nano-TiO2 in a holistic way. In the BASE scenario, all the stocks exhibit an 288 exponential-like increase over time. This is caused by both the primary input increasing yearly (i.e. in-289 creased stock production) and ENM accumulation in each compartment from year to year; especially 290 in those stocks which are currently considered as final sinks (landfills, soil and sediment). 291
292
Page 11 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
308
Total cessation of ENM use (BAN Scenario): Understanding memory effects 309
Yearly ENM production inputs to the consumption, release and distribution system are allocated by re-310 leases into environmental and technical compartments which are split into two fractions: the portion 311 which is immediately released and that which stays in the in-use stock for a pre-determined amount of 312 time depending on the product life-cycle. The differentiation between these two fractions is most evi-313 dent if we hypothesise a ban of new ENM production in order to visualise the continued release of 314 ENM material from the in-use stock when there is no new production input. 315
In some cases, such as with nano-TiO2, immediate releases dominate the total flow of material, with a 316 lesser fraction being retained in products and released over many years (Figure 3a). This is based on 317 the fact that a significant fraction of products containing nano-TiO2 (e.g. cosmetics, sunscreens at 60% 318 of the total current material distribution) are slated for immediate release whereas a smaller fraction 319 (e.g. paints, consisting of 9% of the total material distribution) have a greater proportion of material al-320
Page 12 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
located to the in-use stock for releases at later times. Because there is a high amount of initial release 321 in consumer products that have fast releases, when a ban is introduced the amount of product in the 322 market will fall immediately; i.e. the in-use stock from these sources will be fully depleted soon after 323 the ban is enforced. Other uses of nano-TiO2, such as the inclusion in paints and coatings, have a long-324 er lifespan due to their association with building materials and so a smaller released mass will continue 325 even after the ban is in place as depicted by the small trough in Figure 3a. However, since this use 326 makes up a smaller mass of nano-TiO2, only about 12% of total nano-TiO2 released or produced would 327 be available for release in the longer-term (i.e. approximately around 80 years after its production) in-328 use stock. 329
In other cases, as with CNT (Figure 3b), the release from the long-term in-use stocks dominates all 330 immediate releases. As the main source of using CNT is currently in polymer composites and only 1% 331 of this material is released in the first year of use, the bulk of the material flow will be dominated by 332 the scheduled in-use stock release. The lifetime of plastic items is distributed around the 8 years and 333 releases of CNT into environmental and technical compartments are scheduled according to the dis-334 posal of these items. Therefore, even after the ban has come into place, release of CNT from products 335 produced before the ban will continue. Similar to the case of nano-TiO2, due to the fact that a very 336 small fraction (around 3%) of CNT is applied in paints, there is also a much delayed emergence of re-337 lease after the ban takes place. 338
This hypothetical ban exemplifies how the improved DP-MFA and its possibility to model memory ef-339 fects can more accurately assess the timeline of ENM releases into environmental and technical sys-340 tems, because releases are more closely coupled with the life-cycle of individual products and realistic 341 release rates from year to year. Older, static versions of the model did not account for timed releases 342 and so this model memory effect (i.e. the accumulation of ENM in stocks and timed releases) was not 343 considered. As more products reach the market which contain ENM, the in-use stock will become in-344 creasingly important as essentially an additional, delayed source of particles to environmental and 345 technical systems. In previous models, the production values in one year were completely distributed 346 to the environment in a single year, an assumption that our dynamic modelling has clearly shown to 347 not be representative for the ENM investigated. 348
349
350
Page 13 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
357
Importance of timed release for the accumulation of ENM in sinks 358
The model memory of scheduled releases has further-reaching effects than a simple delayed release to 359 the distribution portion of the model. This also influences the timing of ENM mass that reaches each 360 system compartment and final sink. Following the hypothetical ban of all ENM production in 2020, 361 we can note a few trends differentiating the various ENM and how they are allocated to environmental 362 and technical compartments, even with no further inputs to the system (Figures 3c and 3d.). 363
For example, nano-TiO2 exhibits an initial drop of the in-use stock with a longer tail until it is depleted 364 and this is directly due to the importance of the distribution of the ENM in each of the product sectors 365 (Figure 3c). In this case, the products which dominate the distribution of ENM in products are those 366 where there is a high amount of ENM that are released on a short time scale to one environmental sec-367 tor (e.g. nanoTiO2 release from cosmetics/sunscreens release to the wastewater treatment system and 368 ultimately to the landfill). This will cause an initial depletion of the in-use stock shortly after the ban in 369
Page 14 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
2020 (Figure 3c), and subsequent distribution of most of the ENM mass amongst the affected sinks. 370 Therefore the accumulation of nano-TiO2 in sediment and soil will not significantly increase a few 371 years after the ban because the in-use stock and flow of ENM contributing to these compartments has 372 been depleted. However, other uses of nano-TiO2, such as the inclusion in paints and coatings associ-373 ated with building materials, have a longer lifespan (80 years) and so additional releases of ENM to 374 the landfill are anticipated even after the ban is in place. In brief, environmental and technical com-375 partments remain at a near steady-state condition with no further input into the system almost immedi-376 ately after the ban is in effect for nearly 80 years until the release of nano-TiO2 from construction 377 waste is scheduled for release, after which the in-use stocks of nano-TiO2 are finally diminished from 378 the pre-ban timeline. 379
Conversely, CNT are currently dominantly used in consumer products such as plastics that have a very 380 low initial release (1%) and thus a longer lagged release from the product into environmental and 381 technical systems. While the in-use stock of CNT is slowly consumed post ban, a continuous addition 382 of CNT to sink compartments will occur several years after the ban due to the delayed releases of CNT 383 from plastics (see from 2020 to 2040 in Figure 3d). It is only when these stocked products are finally 384 disposed of at the end of the life cycle into the landfill (averaging 10 years post-production) that the 385 mass of ENM emitted reaches a steady state; a situation that is directly dictated by the length of prod-386 uct use and release rates of ENM. 387
388
Influence of variable ENM product incorporation, use and selective ban scenarios on ENM mass flows 389
When hypothetical developments in the use of ENM in products based on selective policy bans or de-390 velopment and implementation of new technology are considered, the mass of ENM reaching surface 391 water and soil in some instances could change substantially in the near future. Factors influencing the 392 change in the magnitude of release compared to the BASE scenario include 1) share of products af-393 fected by the change in ENM usage, 2) ENM timed release scheme over the product lifetime (i.e. short 394 vs. long in-use phase), 3) destination of ENM after product release (i.e. environmental or technical 395 compartment) and 4) the transfer parameters over the entire process, both in the release and distribu-396 tion modules. The development of ENM emissions between 2015 and 2030 in the various scenarios 397 envisioned can be compared to the BASE scenario to better grasp to what extent changes in ENM us-398 age may affect the mass of ENM reaching the environment (Figure 4). 399
400
Page 15 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
412
Given that cosmetics constitute up to a 60% share of all nano-TiO2 uses 3 and the majority of this frac-413 tion is released immediately to surface water after the product use phase, once the mass of this fraction 414 of the nano-TiO2 product distribution decreases there will be a significant reduction of total nano-TiO2 415 emitted to the surface water (Figure 4a). In the BASE scenario, the evolution of emissions into surface 416 water has a positive correlation with annual nano-TiO2 input, as noted by the steady increase in nano-417 TiO2 to surface water between 2015 and 2020, but remains constant thereafter because the input mass 418 was fixed to the 2020 value in future projections. The discrepancy between nano-TiO2 emissions of the 419 BASE and BAN-Cos scenarios demonstrate the effect of this cosmetics ban, where the annual emis-420
Page 16 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
sions of nano-TiO2 to surface water would be projected to decrease by nearly three quarters. From 421 2020 onwards, the difference between the BASE and BAN-COS remains steady because the total in-422 put into both modelled systems remains constant due to steady inputs from other product sectors using 423 nano-TiO2, for example cleaning agents and consumer appliances. 424
Conversely, little difference in both the annual emission to and the accumulation of nano-TiO2 in soil 425 between the BASE scenario and INC-Concr were observed between 2015 and 2030 (Figure 4b and 426 4c). This result stems from two sources. Firstly, the transfer data for nano-TiO2 applied in concrete 427 were the same as those used for paints, where only 1% is released during use and 99% is defined as 428 EoL release. Because emissions to natural and urban soils account for only 25% of the total use re-429 lease, a mere 0.25% additional yearly increase derives from the increased use of nano-TiO2 in con-430 crete. Secondly, because the bulk of the release is slated to occur at the EoL phase, averaging 80 years 431 post-production, we would only expect the in-use stocks of our hypothetical system to deviate from 432 the BASE scenario on a longer time frame. However, even then low emissions to soil are expected 433 given that after building demolition, as 30% of concrete goes to landfill and 70% is recycled. There-434 fore the addition of nano-TiO2 to concrete appears to not expose soils to a large increase of ENM when 435 compared to all other uses of nano-TiO2 and the accompanying releases. 436
There is approximately a 20% reduction in nano-Ag emissions to surface water when the BASE and 437 BAN-Tex scenarios are compared (Figure 4d). The mass of Ag released from the textile during the use 438
phase, which has shown to be variable under different use conditions 31, 32 , has significant ramifications 439 both on the initial release to water but also on the mass of Ag remaining on the textile that will further 440 be distributed during the EoL phase. Secondly, releases to the surface water from nano-textiles first 441 must pass through the wastewater treatment plant, and so any variations in this transfer factor would 442 directly affect the calculated amount of nano-Ag emitted to surface water. 443
A significant difference between the BASE scenario and a hypothetical change to ENM use is found in 444 the case of increased CNT application in tyres (INC-Tyr) and the subsequent annual emission to and 445 accumulation of CNT in soil (Figure 4e and 4f). Approximately 9% of the total mass of the tyre is ex-446 pected to be lost during the use phase (Table S2), which corresponds to the 9% out of the 10% (Table 447 1) of CNT applied in tyres being released during the use phase. Out of this fraction, approximately 448 half is estimated to be destined for the soil environmental compartment. This application accounts for 449 up to 0.5% of the total share of CNT consumption in all product categories. By the year 2030, the an-450 nual CNT emission to soil rises to 40 tonnes in contrast to approximately 20 tonnes for the BASE sce-451 nario; for the accumulated CNT mass in soil, the value of the INC-Tyr scenario is projected to rise to 452 approximately 500 tonnes by 2030. 453
Page 17 of 22
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
Calculating the ratio of the accumulated mass in the soil to the annual emission to this compartment, 454 we see that in the early stages of increased CNT use (e.g. 2015), the annual flow accounts for approx-455 imately one fifth of the accumulated mass, by 2020 this value drops to less than one tenth. 456
457
Implications of the model results 458
For all the scenarios developed in this work and the flows quantified for extended periods of time, we 459 did not include any transformation reactions of the ENM after they end up in environmental compart-460 ments. We have only taken into account some specific and well-studied transformations of ENM dur-461 ing wastewater treatment (sulfidation of nano-Ag and ZnO) and incineration processes (combustion of 462 CNT), of which the transformed fraction is represented by the virtual compartment “elimination”. The 463 emissions to landfill, soil, surface water, sediment that we provide therefore constitute a likely upper 464 bound for material flows depending on the ENM investigated. The mass flows given in Figure 4 may 465 therefore be lower for a reactive material, such as nano-Ag, which can dissolve or undergo chemical 466 transformation reactions. These mass flows are also one of the primary input data for environmental 467
fate models that describe mechanistically the fate of ENM in natural systems 33-36 . In these models the 468 further dissolution/transformation over time of the deposited masses can be predicted. 469
The ability to predict the dynamic flows of ENM to several environmental and technical compartments 470 based on prospective changes in materials development is an important development for the risk as-471 sessment of ENM. The risk, comprised of the combination of hazard and exposure, of using nano-472 enhanced products can change over time depending on the flow of ENM to the environment. The 473 emissions data generated from our previous (static) modelling efforts 3, 7 have long stood as bench-474 marks for the likely exposure values in the risk equation and therefore were used as realistic ENM 475
concentrations when evaluating the fate of ENM in the environment 33, 37, 38 or to assess environmental 476 risks of ENM39, 40. A more refined, time-resolved analysis of this emissions data assists in more realis-477 tic risk assessments as well as provides improved input data for environmental fate models, such as to 478 follow the heteroagglomeration in natural waters38. By better assessing the relative impact of the use 479 of given nano-enabled products over time both researchers and regulators may be able to better assess 480 the pros and cons of implementing new products and the potential for far reaching affects that curbing 481 ENM usage may have on various environmental sectors. 482

referenceMentions.context: Current modelling efforts have approximated the mass 47 flows to and the concentrations of ENM in environmental and technical compartments, allowing 48 researchers from many disciplines to perform more realistic studies concerning environmental 49 health and safety.(1-10) The preferred approach follows a life-cycle principle tracking ENM mass50 flows (material flow analysis, MFA) from the production of ENM through to their final settling 51 place in environmental or waste streams.

Additionally, 177 some transformation processes of ENM may make them inherently loose their “nano” proper178 ties, such as when ENM dissolve, become irreversibly complexed to natural particles, or be 179 transformed during some stages of the product life-cycle.(24) Therefore, the values given for ENM 180 in environmental sinks represent upper limits for total ENM concentrations.

metadata.abstractText: 25 The need for an environmental risk assessment for engineered nanomaterials (ENM) necessi26 tates the knowledge about their environmental emissions. Material flow models (MFA) have 27 been used to provide predicted environmental emissions but most current nano-MFA models 28 consider neither the rapid development of ENM production nor the fact that a large proportion 29 of ENM are entering an in-use stock and are released from products over time (i.e. have a lag 30 phase). Here we use dynamic probabilistic material flow modelling to predict scenarios of the 31 future flows of four ENM (nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, nano-Ag and CNT) to environmental com32 partments and to quantify their amounts in (temporary) sinks such as the in-use stock and (“fi33 nal”) environmental sinks such as soil and sediment. In these scenarios, we estimate likely fu34 ture amounts if the use and distribution of ENM in products continues along current trends (i.e. 35 a business-as-usual approach) and predict the effect of hypothetical trends in the market devel36 opment of nanomaterials, such as the emergence of a new widely used product or the ban on 37 certain substances, on the flows of nanomaterials to the environment in years to come. We show 38 that depending on the scenario and the product type affected, significant changes of the flows 39 occur over time, driven by the growth of stocks and delayed release dynamics. 40
